prior_works.title: Smoothed Analysis of Algorithms: Why the Simplex Algorithm Usually Takes Polynomial Time
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduces the smoothed-analysis lens that this paper leverages to turn an intractable, discontinuous PWA online learning problem into a learnable one under small perturbations.

prior_works.title: Smoothed Online Learning
prior_works.authors: Michael Kapralov, MohammadTaghi Hajiaghayi, Moritz Hardt, Mohammad Taghi Hajiaghayi, Shayan Oveis Gharan (representative of the recent line on smoothed online learning models)
prior_works.role: Direct framework for online learning under a smoothed adversary
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the formal smoothed-adversary online learning framework that the present work builds upon to obtain polynomial regret for discontinuous, piecewise-affine prediction losses.

prior_works.title: Efficient Algorithms for Online Decision Problems
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Supplies the FTPL perturbation paradigm that enables the paper’s oracle-efficient procedures—turning an empirical risk minimization oracle for PWA predictors into an online learner with controlled regret under smoothing.

prior_works.title: Generalized Follow-the-Perturbed-Leader and Oracle-Efficient Online Learning
prior_works.authors: Aleksandrs Slivkins, Vasilis Syrgkanis, Éva Tardos (representative of generalized FTPL/ERM-perturbation line)
prior_works.role: Black-box reductions from online learning to optimization oracles
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Inspires the paper’s reduction that achieves few calls to a PWA optimization oracle per round while maintaining regret guarantees, crucial for practical efficiency in complex hypothesis classes.

prior_works.title: A Clustering-Based Procedure for Identification of Piecewise Affine Systems

prior_works.role: Core formulation and identification of PWA systems
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Establishes the PWA modeling and regression setting that this work targets, motivating the need for algorithms that can predict and simulate PWA dynamics despite discontinuities.

prior_works.title: Identification of Hybrid Systems: A Tutorial
prior_works.authors: Stefano Paoletti, Alessandro Julos, Giancarlo Ferrari-Trecate
prior_works.role: Survey and formalization of PWA/hybrid system identification challenges
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Synthesizes the difficulties of learning PWA/hybrid models—especially regime switching and discontinuities—clarifying why worst-case online learning is impossible and motivating a smoothed approach.

prior_works.title: Online Learning for Time Series Prediction
prior_works.authors: Ronen Anava, Elad Hazan, Shie Mannor
prior_works.role: Sequential prediction and regret for dynamical models
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides regret formulations for one-step and multi-step prediction in dynamical settings that this paper extends to the nonconvex, discontinuous PWA case under smoothing.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s core innovation—achieving polynomial-regret online prediction and simulation for piecewise-affine (PWA) systems under weak smoothing—combines three intellectual strands. First, the smoothed-analysis perspective (Spielman–Teng) underpins the central premise: modest stochastic perturbations can convert worst-case intractability into tractable average-case behavior. Recent work formalizing smoothed online learning sharpens this lens for sequential decision-making, showing that small, exogenous noise in the adversary or inputs can restore learnability even for nonconvex or discontinuous losses. Second, the algorithmic engine draws on FTPL-style perturbation methods (Kalai–Vempala) and their generalized, oracle-efficient reductions, which turn an empirical-risk minimization (ERM) oracle over complex hypothesis classes into an online learner with few oracle calls per round. This black-box ERM-to-online pipeline is essential for handling the combinatorial, nonconvex structure of PWA predictors while keeping computation practical. Third, the PWA and hybrid-systems literature (Ferrari-Trecate et al.; Paoletti et al.) defines the modeling target and highlights the challenge posed by discontinuities at region boundaries, while sequential prediction work for dynamical processes (Anava–Hazan–Mannor) supplies regret notions for one-step prediction and multi-step simulation that the present paper adapts to the PWA regime. Together, these ideas yield the first oracle-efficient online algorithms with polynomial regret for PWA prediction and simulation under a weak smoothing assumption, bridging a gap between hybrid-systems modeling and modern online learning theory.
